node.title: Man Who Threatened Congressmembers If They Didn't Support Trump Sentenced to Nearly 3 Years
node.alt: Ryder Winegar was given a 33-month sentence along with a $15,000 fine after he pleaded guilty to threatening six members of Congress over not supporting former President Donald Trump. In this photo, the presidential inaugural platform is under construction in front of the US Capitol as part of the West Front lawn is closed to the public November 9, 2020 on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC.
node.description: Ryder Winegar was accused of threatening to hang lawmakers if they wouldn't "get behind Donald Trump" in phone messages left on the morning of Dec. 16, 2020.
node.content:
["Ryder Winegar, 34, was sentenced to nearly three years in prison after pleading guilty to making threatening phone calls to members of Congress who didn't support former President Donald Trump.", "Winegar, of Amherst, was accused of threatening to hang lawmakers if they wouldn't \"get behind Donald Trump\" in phone messages left on the morning of Dec. 16, 2020. Officials said that he left his name and telephone number in some messages, according to The Associated Press. He left messages for three senators and three representatives, the Department of Justice reported.", "In one message, Winegar allegedly said, \"I got some advice for you. Here's the advice, Donald Trump is your president. If you don't get behind him, we're going to hang you until you die.\"", "U.S. Capitol Police officers first tried to interview Winegar on Dec. 20, 2020 but were refused. Winegar flew to Brazil the next day alone before authorities could come back with warrants. He was arrested on Jan. 11, 2021, when he returned to the United States.", "\"And it really, really, it boils down to two camps. You either support our president, support liberty, and this global f*** this h**o, uh, vaccination Jewish agenda, or you're not. In which case we're going to f***ing kill you. Do you understand?\" Winegar allegedly said in another message.", "Winegar originally pleaded guilty on Aug. 6, 2021, and has been in custody since his arrest in January. He will have to pay a $15,000 fine along with his 33-month sentencing.", "\"Today's sentencing sends a clear message that threats of violence have no place in our political discourse,\" said Acting U.S. Attorney John F. Farley. \"While all citizens are free to express their political opinions, it is unlawful to threaten to commit acts of violence against members of Congress or members of the state legislature.\"", "For more reporting from the Associated Press, see below. ", "", "

", "After his arrest in January, investigators learned that he also sent a death threat via email to a state lawmaker.", "His lawyer had asked for supervised release or home confinement.", "\"He does not and will not seek to excuse his actions, but he would like the Court to know that he is humiliated not just by his actions but as well by the thought patterns that caused him to engage in this conduct,\" his lawyer Charles Keefe, said in a court document.", "Prosecutors objected, noting that Winegar fled to Brazil the day after police first tried to question him last December."]
